headline.main: 7 Sentenced in First Tiananmen Square Protest Trials

byline.original: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Ending its first political trials arising from the Tiananmen Square democracy movement, a Chinese court announced today that seven democracy campaigners had been sentenced to two to four years in jail. Four of those sentenced were students on a most-wanted list. It was not clear whether the other three were students or workers. The court also convicted two others of minor crimes, but exempted them from punishment.

headline.main: Another Major '89 Protester Is Placed on Trial in Beijing

docs.lead_paragraph: China opened court proceedings today against another prominent dissident, Liu Xiaobo, who was involved in the Beijing protests of 1989. Mr. Liu, a bold literary critic who returned from the United States to take part in the democracy movement in the spring of 1989, was charged with "counterrevolutionary propaganda and incitement." Mr. Liu, 35 years old, was apparently detained early in June. China announced sentences this month for one group of political offenders, but has not announced the results of any other political trials since.

headline.main: In Murky Trials, China Buries Tiananmen Affair

docs.snippet: They are only tiny trial notices, scribbled on pieces of paper that crackle in the wind on a board outside the Intermediate People's Court, but they suggest that China now hopes to write the last chapter in the chronicles of the 1989 Tiananmen demo

byline.original: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: They are only tiny trial notices, scribbled on pieces of paper that crackle in the wind on a board outside the Intermediate People's Court, but they suggest that China now hopes to write the last chapter in the chronicles of the 1989 Tiananmen democracy movement. While the world is absorbed by the crisis in the Persian Gulf, China is putting on trial the boldest and most prominent students and intellectuals who were the backbone of the democracy movement. Nine people have been sentenced so far, drawing punishment ranging from suspended sentences to up to four years in prison, and 14 more are now on trial or awaiting sentences.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: In the 18 months since the Chinese Government crushed the democracy movement that she helped lead, Chai Ling has tried to put the memory of the tanks rumbling through Tiananmen Square behind her. But the news that Beijing recently sentenced a group of her fellow students to prison for the protests -- and planned to put more on trial -- has rekindled for Ms. Chai painful images of the night of June 3-4, 1989, forcing her to confront suppressed emotions of frustration, rage and guilt.

byline.original: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Wang Dan, the scrawny Beijing University student who was the foremost leader of the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy movement, went on trial today on harges of "counterrevolutionary propaganda and incitement." Mr. Wang, a 22-year-old who had been studying history until his arrest, was No. 1 on a police list of 21 most-wanted students. A serious, unsmiling youth with thick glasses, Mr. Wang exhibited a determination and commitment to political change that inspired thousands of students to take to the streets.

headline.main: Beijing Journal; Whatever the High Walls Hide, It Isn't Opulence

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Behind 15-foot walls in the center of the capital is a vast and lovely park called Zhongnanhai, which was once a playground of the emperors and their concubines and which today doubles as the Communist version of a Forbidden City and the most exclusive retirement home in the world. Mao Zedong moved into a Ming Dynasty pavilion in Zhongnanhai on the triumph of the Communist Revolution in 1949. Ever since then, Zhongnanhai has been the headquarters of the Communist Party and Chinese Government, as well as the home of high leaders.

docs.snippet: A Chinese court today sentenced the nation's leading human rights advocate to seven years in prison and its foremost student leader to a four-year term for "counterrevolutionary propaganda and incitement" during the Tiananmen democracy movement.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: A Chinese court today sentenced the nation's leading human rights advocate to seven years in prison and its foremost student leader to a four-year term for "counterrevolutionary propaganda and incitement" during the Tiananmen democracy movement. Six other democratic militants were sentenced to terms ranging from two to five years, the official New China News Agency said, while 66 others were apparently released. By Chinese standards, the sentences were relatively lenient as counterrevolutionary offenses can bring the death penalty.

byline.original: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The three-hour trial of Wang Dan, the student leader sentenced Saturday to four years in prison, unfolded as smoothly as the script allowed it, and while the players assumed Mr. Wang's guilt, all eyes were on his performance. The two dozen or so Tiananmen Square trials held in recent weeks were closed to journalists and other foreigners, but bits and pieces gathered through people allowed to watch Mr. Wang's trial suggested that the process was more theatrical than judicial.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nei jin, wai song, says China's Communist leadership, meaning that its policy of fierce domestic political repression can coexist with harmonious relations with the outside world. Not so is the outside world's only decent response. Last week, Beijing convicted and sentenced eight student and intellectual leaders of the 1989 democracy movement, after trials that excluded family, journalists and independent observers. Government-appointed defense counsels readily conceded the defendants' guilt.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The Government put a leading democracy advocate on trial today for "conspiracy to overthrow the Government," an offense that can bring the death penalty, and barred his wife from attending the trial. The defendant, Chen Ziming, a 38-year-old social scientist and newspaper publisher, has reportedly been on a hunger strike, and today he appeared thin and weak, said a Chinese who saw him.
